abstract: The Upshot; Tyler Cowen Economic View column observes that growing number of 'equal' marriages among professionals, in which both partners are successful in their careers, may be contributing to income inequality across nation; argues that 'power couple' trend causes money and power to become more densely clustered.
lead_paragraph: Assortative mating, or the pairing of people with similar incomes and education, clusters money and talent in high-powered families and helps propagate inequality across generations.

headline.main: The Marriages of Power Couples Reinforce Income Inequality
headline.print_headline: How a Marriage of Equals May Promote Inequality

snippet: Assortative mating, or the pairing of people with similar incomes and education, clusters money and talent in high-powered families and helps propagate inequality across generations.
